predicted_summary.wugNATSS-billsum(on-un: Implementation of Torture Export Control Act of 2004 - Amends the Export Administration Act of 1979 to prohibit the President from exporting any item on the United States Munitions List which is designed, manufactured, or manufactured for use in the export of torture (or for the use of torture) equipment. Makes a specified export license and export license available to the Secretary of State for export of such items.Directs the Secretary of Commerce to establish a program to provide training to law enforcement personnel in countries where there are political or free expression activities, including torture, extrajudicial killing, torture, and abuse of citizens of the United States or other countries of the Organization of American States (U.S.) or of the European Union (or any successor group).Prohibits the export to any country of crime control and detection instruments and equipment (except pursuant to an individual export license) unless the Secretary of State determines that such country's government has repeatedly engaged in acts of torture: (1) in the development and use of terrorism; (2) in the detention and interrogation of individuals for human rights abuses, including torture; (3) in the commission of acts of international terrorism; and (4) in the production of weapons of mass destruction (including nuclear weapons) that could be used to threaten national security. Requires the Secretary to: (1) review such export restrictions; and (2) impose a quantitative limitation on the export of such items to any government that has repeatedly violated such restrictions. Sets forth exceptions to such export prohibitions, including those for countries that are members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization or are major non-nato allies. ProhibitStipulates the Secretary's approval of the export, other than pursuant to a license, of: (1) crime control, detection, and detection equipment (including equipment especially susceptible to abuse as implements of torture); (2) goods, services, or technology to the government of any country that has twice been determined to have engaged in torture; and (3) goods, technology, or services (including software) to any non-U.S. person that has been determined by the U.S, through the Department of State, to have repeatedly engaged, in torture.Prohibits the export of such items: (1) to any country where the government has engaged in or condones torture; (2) to any entity that is known to have engaged in acts of torture; or (3) to any foreign country that has been designated as a state sponsor of torture or where the Secretary of State determines that such action is likely to result in torture.Directs the Secretary to: (1) establish and maintain a list of approved crime control and detection equipment; (2) ensure that the head of all appropriate agencies consulted before an individual export license is granted; and (3) publish the list in the Federal Register.Directs: (1) the Secretary of State to ensure that the responsible official of the Bureau of democracy, human rights and labor is fully involved in reviewing proposed export licenses; and (2) the Secretary and the appropriate officials of the Department of State, the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to provide appropriate technical assistance in such review.
predicted_summary.wugwATSS-billsum(on-un: implementers of torture export control Act of 2004 - Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to prohibit the export to any foreign country of any goods, services, technology, or technology (except those specifically authorized by the Secretary of State) that would be used to torture any person in that country. Requires the President to ensure that the export of such goods and services does not pose a risk to human rights or other rights.Directs the Secretary of Commerce to report to Congress regarding the use of torture by foreign countries designated as major non-nato allies or by countries with which the United States has entered into bilateral or multilateral agreements for the exportation of goods or services, including related technical assistance.Directs the Secretary to establish a license system to export crime control and detection instruments and equipment to countries that have repeatedly engaged in acts of torture. Prohibits the export of such items to a country that is a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) or a major non-NATO ally. Specifies exceptions.Prohibits the export of such items to countries that have been determined by the Secretary to have engaged in torture. Allows the Secretary, with the concurrence of the Secretary of State, to approve export of items for such countries only if the end user, or the export license holder, has not engaged in such torture. Sets forth congressional reporting requirements.Directs the Secretary to establish and maintain, with the concurrence of the Secretary of State, a list of specified crime control and detection instruments that are especially susceptible to abuse.Secretary of State shall ensure that the responsible official of the Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor is fully involved in the review of proposed export licenses with respect to the export of goods or services to the United States.

predicted_summary.wugNATSS-billsum(on-un: United States Buffalo Act of 1997 - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to mint and issue five-cent silver coins in commemoration of the U.S. Buffalo Act.Mandates that: (1) all coins minted under this Act be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities; (2) all Federal coins minted after December 31, 2000, be issued only in dollar formats; and (3) all coin design be selected by the Secretary of the Treasury, after consultation with the Citizens Commemorative Coin advisory committee.Prohibits any provision of law governing procurement or public contracts from being applicable to the procurement of goods and services necessary for the implementation of this Act, except that the Secretary shall: (1) make bulk sales of the coins at a reasonable discount; and (2) accept prepaid orders for such coins before their issuance.Requires all surcharges received from the sale of coins to be paid promptly to the National Museum of the American Indian to commemorate the ten-year anniversary of its establishment and supplement its endowment and educational outreach funds.National Credit Union Administration Board - Directs the National Credit union Administration Board to liquidate and dissolve any assets of any depository institution whose deposits are insured by either the Federal deposit insurance corporation or the National credit union administration board.
predicted_summary.wugwATSS-billsum(on-un: United States buffalo nickel Act of 1997 - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to issue five-cent coins emblematic of the United States, based on the original five-dollar coin designed by a Native American, in commemoration of the Native American War.Requires the Secretary of the Treasury to mint and issue such coins in commemoration of American Indian Heritage Month, beginning January 1, 2010. Authorizes appropriations for such coin programs in FY2009-FY2010.Prohibits the Secretary from issuing any coins under this Act after December 31, 2000. Directs that the coins be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the sum of the face value of the coins, the surcharge provided in this Act, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) bulk sales; (2) prepaid orders; and (3) surcharges.Requires all surcharges received from the sale of coins to be paid to the National Museum of the American Indian to commemorate the ten-year anniversary of such museum and to supplement its endowment and educational outreach funds.Requires the credit union to submit to the Secretary a copy of the membership roll. Requires the National Credit Union Administration Board to appoint a Secretary of the Treasury to serve as the Administrator of the Credit Unions.

predicted_summary.wugNATSS-billsum(on-un: respirator access assurance Act of 2005 - Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to establish regulations under which respirator manufacturers and sellers must: (1) comply with performance standards established by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH); (2) maintain compliance with the standards through follow-up field audits; and (3) pay a civil penalty to the Secretary for each violation of such requirement.Requires the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) to maintain a list of approved respirator warning labels and to issue regulations requiring the manufacturer of a respirator to notify NIOSH of its intention to discontinue manufacture or distribution of the respirator.Prohibits Federal or State agencies from requiring manufacturers or sellers of certain respirators to certify in compliance with this Act that they have received the approval of the Secretary of Health and Human Services and the U.S. Bureau of Mines and the Mine Safety and Health Administration (or a certification that such respirators are not in violation of this Act, but are not subject to a defect or warning to effect if they did.Requires withdrawal of approval for certain respirators that fail to comply with design and labeling standards in effect on the date of manufacture. (Sec. 5) This bill preempts state and local laws to the extent that they relate to a respirator's design or labeling. This bill does not preempt federal law, but it does preempt state laws that are applicable to respirators.Applies this Act to any civil action in a Federal or State court on the basis of any legal theory for harm allegedly caused, directly or indirectly, by a respirator, a respirator manufacturer, or a respirator seller.
predicted_summary.wugwATSS-billsum(on-un: respirator access assurance Act of 2005 - Requires the Secretary of Labor, acting through the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), to: (1) establish a performance standard for respirators; (2) certify to the public that approved respirators meet specified performance standards; and (3) publish a list of approved respirator manufacturers and sellers of such respirators. Directs the Secretary to establish standards that require: (1) respirators to meet certain performance standards, including those for protection against exposure to hazardous materials and the environment; (2) the respirator must not fail to perform the functions of a respirator in specified ways; (3) it must prevent the spread of hazardous materials; and (4) it must protect individuals from exposure to such hazardous materials. (Sec. 4) Prohibits manufacturers or sellers from discriminating against any person in determining whether a respirator is safe or not. Allows the manufacturer or seller to make a claim that a respirator meets the performance standards if: (1) the respirator is approved by the Secretary; and (2) the seller has determined that the respirator does not meet the standards. (Currently, this requirement applies only to certain respirators that are manufactured or sold under the trade name of a third party.) Requires the BLS to establish regulations to ensure that respirators are approved and certified by the same manufacturer and seller for use in the same market as the approved respirator. Prohibit the Secretary from issuing any certification that requires a respirator not meet performance standards.Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to determine whether there is a violation of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FDCA) relating to the use of respirators. Requires that the Secretary: (1) report to Congress regarding any such violation; and (2) issue regulations to establish the standard for use of the respirator in cases of noncompliance with the FDCA.Requires a manufacturer of a respirator to submit to the Secretary of Labor and the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) a plan for compliance with this Act. Requires such plan to include: (1) the respirator's intended use and protection against inhalation of hazardous atmospheres; (2) a plan to provide for the replacement of respirators within 24 hours if the manufacturer fails to submit the plan; and (3) a certification of compliance by the Secretary and the NIOSH.Requires manufacturers of respirators to label their products with specified information, including: (1) a statement that the respirator is not approved by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST); and (2) a notice that the manufacturer and seller have failed to comply with the design and labeling requirements of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FFDCA).Requires a manufacturer of a respirator to comply with specified design and labeling requirements (including the requirement that the respirator not be manufactured or distributed in violation of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act).This bill applies to any civil action in a federal or state court on the basis of any legal theory, for harm allegedly caused, directly or indirectly by a respirator, a respirator manufacturer, or a respirator seller.

predicted_summary.wugNATSS-billsum(on-un: Amends the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act to allow the fox corporation to select timber land within six miles of the city limits if it determines that the land selected will be used for wildlife management or to protect the city's home rule.Provides for land selection by fox in Alaska: (1) specified rural areas in specified communities; and (2) specified Alaska Native villages. Provides that land selection shall not be required to be located within the boundaries of any Indian reservation or Indian community.Requires that certain lands selected be held in trust for the benefit of Alaska Natives, and that the lands held in trusts be used for conservation, public safety, and public welfare.<n>Provides that, if the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is not enacted and the selection or conveyance of land is not authorized, then the Secretary shall take into trust land and convey that land, subject to specified conditions.Directs the Secretary to convey the subsurface estate to the Bureau of Land Management to the sealaska corporation. to convey to the fox an easement to the land specified above.Declares that the conveyance of land to the fox and Alaska Native Corporation shall be considered to fulfill the entitlement of such Corporation to: (1) lands under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act; and (2) the lands in the U.S. Virgin Islands and Guam.
predicted_summary.wugwATSS-billsum(on-un: Provides that if the fox corporation and other village corporations in Alaska select land within a home rule city and that land is not available for selection under the home rule, such land shall be considered part of the city's property for purposes of such home rule. (Sec. 3) Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) the selection of land within the city limits; (2) the rights of residents in the city to use such land; and (3) the rights and obligations of the United States.Alaska Native Land Settlement Act - Amends the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act to revise the restrictions on land selected by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to provide that specified lands shall be considered to have been selected under the Act and shall not be considered until the Secretary of the Interior determines that: (1) all of the lands selected are located within the applicable Indian reservation; and (2) all lands that are not specified lands in the area of specified interest have been determined to be suitable for selection.Provides that specified land selected for conveyance under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act shall not be required to select or receive conveyance of approximately 160 acres of unconveyed Federal land located within Alaska.Directs the Secretary to convey specified lands within the boundary of the National Forest System to the Alaska Department of Fish and Wildlife Services. Requires the land conveyed to the Department to be held in trust for the benefit of the State of Alaska and to be managed in accordance with the laws of the state.Directs the Secretary to convey the subsurface estate to the National Park Service (NPS) and the National Forest System (NFS) to the fox estate. (Sec.Provides that the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act shall be the sole legal entity to administer any claims arising out of this conveyance. Provides that: (1) this conveyance shall not be considered to be a relinquishment of rights under this conveyance; and (2) the State of Alaska shall be responsible for ensuring that the conveyance is made to the State and to any other entity that may be required under this agreement.

predicted_summary.wugNATSS-billsum(on-un: Super-efficient appliance incentives and market transformation Act of 2007 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) expand the tax credit for energy efficient appliances to include dishwashers and water heaters; (2) make the energy efficient appliance tax credit permanent; (3) establish a new tax credit amount for qualified appliances; and (4) extend the credit through 2012.Sets forth water consumption limits for: (1) dishwashers; (2) top- loading clothes washers; and (3) clothes washers. Sets forth a civil penalty for violation of the Act, including a violation for which a manufacturer is not liable.Sets a minimum water consumption factor of . 7.5, and a maximum water efficiency factor of 2.2. Sets a monetary limit of $250 for a residential model clothes washer which meets or exceeds 2.0 mef and does not exceed a 6.0 water conservation factor, and $50 for a commercial model clothes washers which meet or exceeds 2.2 mef, does not meet or exceed 4.5 water conservation factors, and has a maximum energy efficiency factor that is less than 24.9 percent.Energy Conservation Act of 2007 - Amends the Energy Policy Act of 2005 to establish a program under which the Secretary of Energy is authorized to make grants to manufacturers of certain commercial and residential model appliances to assist such manufacturers in achieving energy conservation goals. Authorizes appropriations of $100 per year in the case of a residential model refrigerator for FY2008-FY2010 and FY2009 and $200 per year for each year thereafter for such models which are manufactured in calendar year 2008 and 2010.Sets forth a phase out period for the maximum tax credit amount allowed for the production of energy efficient appliances. Provides for a phaseout of such credit for taxpayers beginning after December 31, 2010.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for use of energy-efficient clothes washers and refrigerators (not to exceed 2 percent of the average annual gross receipts of the taxpayer for the three preceding fiscal years.)Energy Conservation Act - Directs the Secretary of Energy to establish a federal energy conservation standard for refrigerators and other commercial refrigerators, and for use in compliance with the standards, that includes: (1) a minimum water consumption factor of 16 gallons per cycle; (2) a minimum energy efficiency rating of two units of energy efficiency per cubic feet of water; (3) an energy efficiency reduction efficiency rating for each unit of energy savings; and (4) a maximum energy savings rating of five percent per unit of water used.2001 energy conservation standard - Amends the Energy Policy Act of 1992 to establish a new energy conservation credit program, to be administered by the Department of Energy (DOE) in conjunction with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), for use by producers and users of electricity in the United States and other countries.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) extend the tax credit for sales of appliances through December 31, 2008; and (2) allow such credit for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007, for which the credit is determined (in lieu of the alternative minimum tax).
predicted_summary.wugwATSS-billsum(on-un: Super-efficient appliance incentives and market transformation Act of 2007 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) expand the tax credit for energy efficient appliances to include manufacturers of dishwashers and other such appliances; (2) allow a new tax credit equal to 30% of the cost of such appliances produced in 2008; (3) increase the maximum tax credit amount for such appliances to $100,000; and (4) allow tax deductions for the purchase of such products.Authorizes appropriations for FY2008-FY2010 to carry out this Act. Authorizes the Secretary of Energy to make funds available to the Department of Energy (DOE) for the research, development, production, testing, and demonstration (RDT& testing) of alternative energy technologies to increase efficiency and reduce energy consumption. Authorize the Secretary to make grants to private entities for research to test and develop alternative energy and water efficiency technologies in residential dishwashers and top- loading clothes washers.Directs the Secretary of Energy to establish a program through which Federal agencies shall make grants to manufacturers of residential and commercial clothes washers for use in the United States. Authorizes appropriations for such program.Authorizes the Secretary of Energy to make grants to States to assist in implementing and enforcing such standards. Authorizes appropriations to the Secretary for FY2008-FY2010 for the Department of Energy (DOE) to carry out energy conservation programs. AuthorizeS appropriations.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for the purchase of certain energy efficient appliances. Provides for the credit to be paid to a manufacturer for the cost of such appliances to the United States.Directs the Secretary of Energy to establish a program to provide financial incentives for individuals to purchase energy-efficient clothes washers and refrigerators. Requires the Secretary to report to Congress on the impact of this Act on energy savings and the cost savings achieved.Directs the Secretary of Commerce to establish standards for the use of energy in the production, storage, and distribution of goods and services to ensure that the energy efficiency of such products and services are equal, or greater, than that of the energy costs of their use.Requires the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) to establish and enforce regulations to ensure that the water consumption factor for each application to the market of a consumer product is equal to or greater than the water consumed by the total water used in the same cycle of the consumer product in accordance with the standards for consumer products in the market for which the standard is no less than that total water consumption. Authorizes a single-use consumer product to be considered a single producer if the consumer is a single employer.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) allow a new 30% tax credit for investment in renewable energy projects; and (2) make such tax credit refundable for taxable years beginning after 2007.(Sec. 3) This bill amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to modify the labeling requirements for certain appliances. Specifically, the bill applies to certain appliances produced after December 31, 2007, and then to other appliances produced before January 1, 2008.
